info.Find Place: Old Talab near Bhagavati shrine of villages virnora, pernem tq. Goa.
info.Brief Description:
Crude, image of warrior Kulpurusha holding sword and shield 
dressed in dhoti and warriors head dress.
info.Detailed Description:
Crude, image of warrior Kulpurusha holding sword and shield 
dressed in dhoti and warriors head dress.

info.Provenance: Curdi / Kurdi village, Sainguem Taluka, Dist; South Goa
info.Find Place: Curdi / Kurdi Village, Saingum Taluka, Dist. South Goa
info.Brief Description: Sculpture represents four handed Uma-Maheshwar seated on a Nandi
info.Detailed Description:
The composite, ornamented sculpture represents four handed 
Uma-Maheshwar seated on a Nandi with depiction of Kartikeya 
riding on a peacock on the right, and Ganesh seated in Abida 
(folded legs)pose on the left, and a dancing figure on the 
center of the pedestal. Both Uma-Maheshwar are wearing 
Kiritha mukuta. Maheshwar holds a snake in the upper left 
hand.

info.Provenance: Rocky out crop in Curdi village, Saingum Taluka, District South Goa
info.Find Place: Rocky out crop in Curdi village, Saingum Taluka, District South Goa
info.Brief Description: Uma maheshwar head is missing
info.Detailed Description:
Uma-Maheshwar in alingana pose with head of Shiva broken seating on 
nandi and down there is depiction of Ganesh and Shanmukha on peacock.

info.Provenance: Bethki Village, Bisolli Taluka/Ponda Taluka, Goa
info.Brief Description: Inscribed Viragal slab with three sculptured panels
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed Viragal slab with three sculptured panels 
illustrate voluntary immolation of a Hero by fire 
representing the hero seated with folded hands amidst the 
flames. Musician on the left side and a person in an adoring 
attitude accompany the act of self immolation. In the middle 
panels the hero is being lifted to heaven by four apsaras 
(celestial damsels), two of them have chamaras in their 
hands. The upper most panel depicts the hero on his way to 
heaven on horseback in place of his usual seat in heaven. The 
top portion of the slab replicates a two tiered south Indian 
temple sikhara (superstructure).

info.Brief Description:
A rectangular viragal (Hero stone) with tapering top framed 
by an ornamental band with shiva linga.
info.Detailed Description:
A rectangular viragal (Hero stone) with tapering top framed 
by an ornamental band with shiva linga in the middle depicts 
fighting scene in three panels. In the lower panel the hero 
on elephantback is engaged in a battle with foot soilders; 
hero is aiming a spear at the enemies who are aiming swords 
at the hero. The middle panel depicts the hero engaged in a 
groundbattle with enemies; all are holding swords and 
shields.The upper most panel depicts the hero on horseback 
aiming a spear at his enemy who is also on horseback. The 
conical top represents linga worship by the hero in heaven. 
Nandi appears by the side of the linga.

info.Provenance: From an unidentified temple situated near the Mahadeva Temple, Curdi in South Goa District.
info.Find Place: From an unidentified temple situated near the Mahadeva Temple, Curdi in South Goa District.
info.Brief Description: A headless mended sculpture (3 parts ) of a male deity.
info.Detailed Description:
A headless mended sculpture (3 parts ) of a male deity 
subsequntely identified as Vishnu flanked by four  attendants 
- two on each side, with depiction of two elephant at the back 
of flanking attendants.The slenderly carved main deity is 
adorned with an elaborate waistband and an intricate 
ornamental chain below the knees.

info.Provenance: From inner sanctum of Mahadeva temple near Curdi village, Goa.
info.Find Place: From inner sanctum of Mahadeva temple near Curdi village, Goa.
info.Brief Description: Standing Vishnu figure mutilated not compete part of Acc no 05
info.Detailed Description:
Right portion of the broken frame of a Vishnu Vimana figure 
showing two standing attendents. One is holding a snake and 
the other one is in Kalihasta (empty hand). The main deity 
Vishnu was initially flanked by -
two elephants and four attendants (two on each side)and one 
yati.

info.Brief Description:
Image of a Dwarapalika (female gatekeeper) 
on guard.
info.Detailed Description:
Highly embellished image of a Dwarapalika (female gatekeeper) 
on guard.The deity is holding a sword in her right hand and bowl 
in left hand. She is wearing elaborate neck ornament, Jatamukuta 
and garland.The conical topping of the slab is broken.She wears a 
dress of fine drapery.

info.Brief Description:
A highly ornamented sculpture of Uma-Maheshwar in alingana 
posture.
info.Detailed Description:
A highly ornamented sculpture of Uma-Maheshwar in alingana 
posture wearing jatha mukutha with depiction of elaborate, 
ornamental prabhavali behind their heads. Right hand of 
Mahesh is in abhayamudra and the left arm is embracing Uma on 
her shoulder. Uma is depicted with four hands. One right arm 
is broken and the other is embracing Mahesh. In the left hand 
she is holding a lotus (only the stem is visible) and in the 
other hand she is holding a mirror. Both the deities are 
adorned with elaborate ornamentation.

info.Brief Description: Mutilated ornamented stone lintel.
info.Detailed Description:
Mutilated ornamented stone lintel showing five miniature 
replicas of temple Sikharas (superstructure) of Nagara (North 
Indian) and Vesara (blend of South Indian and North Indian) 
styles. Four sikharas are nagara and the fifth one in the 
centre 
replicates vesara sikhara consisting of multiple tiers.

info.Brief Description: Cylindrical Shiva Linga.
info.Detailed Description:
Cylindrical Shiva Linga only Shivbhag is visible. Brahmbhag and 
Vishnubhag are inserted into the wooden pedestal.

info.Find Place: Old Goa (St.Francis of Assisi Church OldGoa)
info.Brief Description:
Shiva-linga consisting of three parts - Bramhabhaga, 
Vishnubhaga and Shivabhaga.
info.Detailed Description:
Shiva - linga consisting of three parts - Bramhabhaga, 
Vishnubhaga and Shivabhaga. (Bramhabhaga is inserted into a 
wooden pedestal).It carries an arrow mark on the shivabhaga 
which is symbolic of phallus.

info.Brief Description:
Standing image of four handed, heavily armed Mahishasura mardini 
on 
a slab (basalt).
info.Detailed Description:
Standing image of four handed, heavily armed Mahishasuramardini 
on a slab (basalt). The furious goddess is depicted as killing a 
buffalo (Mahisha). Her right foot is resting on the ground and 
left foot on the back of the mahisha. She is holding Ayuda 
(Weapons) in her hands (clockwise) (i) Trisula (Trident) 
striking 
on the back of the animal in the lower right hand. (ii) a Sword 
in the upper right hand (iii) a Shield in the upper left hand. 
(iv) The demon mahisha's hair in the lower left hand. The 
Buffalo 
is facing left. The Simha (lion) Vahana of the goddess is 
attacking the Buffalo is lying on the ground.

Headless, ornamented sculpture of Vetal wearing a garland of 
skulls around the neck. Ribs are clearly visible. The deity has 
a disproportionate body with its torso longer than the legs. It 
wears an elaborate waistband and carries a scorpion over the 
abdomen.The figure is finaly carved. The cult of vetal was more 
popular among the ancient Goans than today.

info.Brief Description: Ornamented, headless, relief of Uma-Maheshwar.
info.Detailed Description:
Ornamented, headless, relief of Uma-Maheshwar image 
(mutilated) seated in abida (folded legs with feet touching 
each other) posture. parvati is seated on the lap of her 
spouse. The couple is embracing each other. Both the deities 
are depicted with elaborate ornamentation. Heads and hands of 
the deities are broken and attributes are lost.

info.Brief Description: A crude relief of Hanuman.
info.Detailed Description:
A crude relief of Hanuman depicted on a large plaque of stone 
with raised head looking towards left side. Right hand is raised 
over his head in kalihasta (without attributes) and the left 
hand is resting on the waist. The tail of Hanuman is raised over 
the right hand.

info.Brief Description: Ornamented relief of Bhairavi on a plaque of stone
info.Detailed Description:
Ornamented relief of Bhairavi on a plaque of stone seated in 
vajrasan posture holding lotus in right hand and a damaru in 
left hand. She is attended by two female chamara (flywhisk) 
bearers on either side. The image is bordered by an ornamental 
band with torana decoration and a kirtimukha in the centre. 
Two elephants are represented below the deity. The crude 
sculpture is in low relief.

info.Brief Description: Stone image of a standing four handed Bhairava.
info.Detailed Description:
Stone image of a standing four handed Bhairava, holding 
(clockwise), (i) broken(ii) Trisula (iii) Damaru (iv) broken. 
The deity is flanked by two attendants; the one on the right 
holding a bow in hand is accompanied by a dog which wears a 
garland of skulls. The slenderly carved, proportionate 
sculpture is bordered by a torana (foliage) decoration.

info.Brief Description: Sculpture of standing vetal.
info.Detailed Description:
Crude, ornamented sculpture of standing vetal with two hands. 
Lower portion of legs are broken. Vetal is wearing and 
ornamented crown and a garland of skulls. The mouth portion of 
the sculpture is damaged.

info.Provenance: Church of St. Francis of Assisi Old Goa
info.Find Place: Church of St. Francis of Assisi,Old Goa
info.Brief Description: Inscribed Tomb stone
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed Tomb stone (Square shaped) with the Portuguese emblem. 
It carries a 10 line inscription in medieval Portuguese dated 
1733 A.D. 
Stone:- Gray sand Stone.

info.Brief Description: Viragal or Hero stone commemorating the death of a hero.
info.Detailed Description:
Viragal or Hero stone commemorating the death of a hero.The 
lower panel depicts a ground battle. The hero is 
disproportionately large statures than his enemy who is much 
smaller in size. Both combatants are charging at each other 
with swords (both hold shields).Two attendants in the upper 
right corner are shown as spectators, admiring the two 
combatants. The one on the left raises both his hands while 
the other one on the right puts his fingers into his mouth in 
an attitude of whistling.Immediately above the scene of 
ground battle, are carved two vessels. The hero stands under 
a parasol within a structural frame on the deck of the better 
preserved vessel on the left and shoots an arrow towards a 
smaller sized man seated in the masthead of the enemy- 
vessel. In the middle panel the hero is seated on a lion-
throne (Sinhasan).He is about to leave this world accompanied 
by his wife who is seated on a smaller throne.In the upper 
most panel he is enthroned in heaven on a decorated asana 
(seat) and flanked by apsaras (celestial damsels).

info.Brief Description: Finely carved Viragal of Hero stone.
info.Detailed Description:
Finely carved Viragal of Hero stone commemorating the death of 
hero in a naval battle. The hero is shown as rising from the 
ground or water and charging the enemy on a vessel with a 
dagger, and the latter is charging the former with spear.The 
upper panel depicts the heroes enthronement in heaven,flanked 
by 
a mob of apsaras;two of them are holding a parasol over is 
head 
and two flanking apsaras on either side of him are fanning him 
with chamaras(fly whisks).

info.Brief Description:
A four panelled Viragal or Hero stone framed by replicas of 
decorative pillars.
info.Detailed Description:
A four paneled Viragal or Hero stone framed by replicas of 
decorative pillars. In the upper panel the hero is depicted as 
seated on high asana(seat) flanked by apsaras and protected 
under parasols. A person is folding hands before couple.In the 
middle panel a naval battle is depicted;four persons are 
fighting. In the lower panel three musicians are playing 
musical instruments. The uppermost panel represents an entire 
hall of a south Indian temple enshrining a linga.

info.Brief Description: Inscription in old Kannada.
info.Detailed Description:
Inscription in old Kannada engraved in 37 horizontal lines and 
one small vertical line. The Lithic records relate to the 
emperor Vira Deva Raya of Vijayanagara dynasty, Dt.1413 A.D.

info.Brief Description:
Viragal or hero stone in three panels punctuated by decorative 
crossbars with torana (beading)decoration.
info.Detailed Description:
Viragal or hero stone in three panels punctuated by decorative 
crossbars with torana (beading)decoration. The lower panel 
depicts a large statures hero being attacked by a small sized 
enemy from a chariot. Two persons are playing drum and gong in 
an attitude of admiring the fight. In the middle panel the 
hero is represented as on his way to heaven accompanied 
musicians and a chamara bearer. In the uppermost panel the 
hero seems to be worshipping a shivalinga in his heavenly 
abode assisted by two celestial beings.

info.Brief Description:
Inscribed viragal or hero stone sculpted in bold relief and 
flanked by replicas of slender pillars.
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed viragal or hero stone sculpted in bold relief and 
flanked by replicas of slender pillars. The hero is 
represented as fighting against his enemies in two panels. In 
the lower panel on horseback and in the middle panel he is 
being slain by his enemies on the wall of a rampart which is 
plastically positioned. The uppermost panel depicting the 
hero's usual seat in heaven is broken.

info.Brief Description:
Two line Persion Inscription engraved on a rectangular slab of 
basalt.
info.Detailed Description:
Two line Persion Inscription engraved on a rectangular slab of 
basalt. Records the foundation / completion of Masjid-i- Fathay 
(mosque of victory)during the reign of Abdul Muzaffar Ibrahim 
Adishah II.

info.Brief Description: Bishop coat of arms
info.Detailed Description:
Bishop coat of arms engraved on a basalt slab. This armorial 
bearing of a Bishop contains a Portuguese emblem in the center 
surrounded by symbolic motifs like loops in high relief and 
drapes symbolized three bishops,two cardinals and the Pope in 
the apex of the Roman catholic church.

info.Brief Description: Portuguese inscription on a rectangular slab
info.Detailed Description:
Portuguese inscription on a rectangular slab sand stone in five 
lines; Coat of arms of a Portuguese nobleman with a Portuguese 
emblem stands out in the center.

info.Brief Description: Inscribed Burial Stone
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed Burial Stone of the 1st Captain of Daman: Dom Diogo 
De Naronha.dated 11th Nov. 1560. It contains Portuguese 
inscription in six lines the compact burial stone with a cap 
bears close resemblance to the Islamic tomstones. The 
inscription on it give the date of demise 11th November 1560.

info.Brief Description: Mutilated viragal (hero stone)
info.Detailed Description:
Mutilated viragal (hero stone) with three defaced human figure; 
two large sized figures are raising their right hands in an 
attitude of blessing and the third figure of much smaller size 
is folding hands in obedience.

info.Brief Description: Hero stone ( broken and mutilated )
info.Detailed Description:
Mutilated viragal or hero stone sculpted from crude basalt. 
Portions of two panels are visible. In the lower panel a female 
dancer is dancing on a raised platform; other figures are 
broken. In the upper panel a vidhyadhara figure is holding a 
garland of flowers; the figure adjacent to it are broken.

info.Brief Description: Broken viragal or hero stone sculpted on three panels.
info.Detailed Description:
Broken viragal or hero stone sculpted on three panels. 
Lowermost panel depicts the immolation of the hero by his 
decapitation. Three persons are standing on either side of the 
hero who is seated on a throne and one person on his right 
side is shown raising a weapon to cut the head off. In the 
middle panel the dead hero is depicted as he is on his way to 
heaven accompanied by musicians. In the uppermost panel the 
hero has arrived in heaven and worships shivalinga;linga is 
broken and only the yonipitha (pedestal) is visible.

info.Brief Description: Inscribed viragal (hero stone) in two panels.
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed viragal (hero stone) in two panels. The lowermost 
panel is broken Which initially depicted the cause of the 
hero's death either by self immolation or by fighting against 
enemies. The middle panel shows the hero being lifted to 
heaven in a scabbard protected under a parasol and accompanied 
by musicians. In the upper panel he is seated in heaven on a 
throne flanked by apsaras (celestial damsels) who are 
attending him with parasols and chamaras (fly whisks).

info.Brief Description: Sati stone with depiction.
info.Detailed Description:
Sati stone with depiction of sati's raised right arm 
projecting from a pillar on the right side of the slab with 
its palm turned towards the on looker in an attitude of 
blessing. In the sculpture husband and wife have appeared 
under the raised arm, on either side of a shivalinga 
indicating shaiva affiliation of the couple.

info.Brief Description: Complete Viragal (hero stone) in three panels.
info.Detailed Description:
Complete Viragal (hero stone) in three panels. The lower most 
panel depicts the heroic death of a hero who is being slain 
by 
his enemy; two persons are playing drum and gong motivatimg 
the figures. The middle 
panel depicts the dead hero being carried to heaven by 
celestial beings amidst beating of drum and gong. The upper 
panel illustrates the victorious hero enthroned in heaven by 
apsaras.

info.Brief Description: Seated nandi
info.Detailed Description:
Headless ornamented seated 
sculpture of nandi in basalt 
stone 
wearing two garlands of small 
bells around its neck.

Oil paintings on wood, 
portrait  of Dom Vasco da Gama.The renowned Portuguese sailor 
who find sea route to India, which opened the the trade from 
west to east,vice versa.he came as a viceroy for a brief period. 
prior to the liberation portrait has 
been taken to Portugal for 
treatment. returned to India 
after that however the upper 
layer of the portrait was 
stripped and below there was 
image of the same person in 
different style.

info.Brief Description:
Oil painting on wood, portrait of 
D. Antanio Brandao (Archbishop) 
Governor. Restored by goanes Da 
Costa in 1894 A.D.
info.Detailed Description:
Dom Pedro de Almeida Portugal 
left for Mozambique handing 
over the Government to Dom 
Antonio Brandao, the 
archbishop and Antonio Paes de 
Sande, who had been names in 
the patent of succession, 
together with the Chancellor 
Francisco Cabral de Almeida 
who was no more by then. On 
the death of the Archbishop in 
July 1679 Antonio  held the government 
alone. He continued to act as 
Governor until succeeded by 
Francisco de Tavora in 1681.

Oil painting on wood, portrait 
of Dom. Joao De Castro,4th Viceroy
from 1545 to 1548 A.D.He initiated preparation of portraits of

preparation of portrait of governors and Viceroys continued. 
This Portrait was carried to Portugal for 
treatment prior to 
independence (1960) ;later 
brought back after the 
treatment however the upper 
;layer of the portrait was 
removed and below it there was 
a painting of same person with 
different style was retained.

info.Brief Description:
Image of Ganesha carved out of a crude Basalt 
stone.
info.Detailed Description:
Defaced, large, image of Ganesha carved out of a crude Basalt 
stone. The seated, two handed image has a large torso with 
broad shoulders giving a giant look to the figure. Face, hands 
and belly are damaged. The right hand is probably in 
abhayamudra (blessing) and in the left hand the deity is 
(probably) holding modhaka (sweet). Trunk and sacred thread 
around the body are visible. The figure is treated roughly 
without any embellishment or ornamentation.

The capital of a pilaster resembling a fruit basket containing 
various kinds of tropical fruits. This architectural member 
(probably) had once adorned the pilaster of a seminary or a 
church as a symbol of prosperity and happiness.

info.Brief Description: Persian inscription in six lines.
info.Detailed Description:
Persian inscription in six lines, dated Hijri year 1003 (1594-
95 A.D.)Dynasty: Adil shahi Ruler: King Ibrahim Adil shah II
Records the construction of the bastion called Burj-i-Fath 
during the tenure of Abdul Malik, Thanedar of the Mahallat of 
Talkofan, during the disturbed times.

info.Brief Description:
Inscribed and sculptured plaque of basalt with marathi 
inscription.
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed and sculptured plaque of basalt with marathi 
inscription. Sun and crescent moon are depicted on the upper 
portion. Below a woman is depicted as taming a cow; behind 
her, a wild animal is stamping a woman laying on her back. 
The inscription records the gift of a village and mentions 
the names of persons Pandusenuaiyya and Kalasavaka. It also 
shows the date saka 1324 Chitra?.Sr. Sud.1.Friady (CE) 1402 
A.D.July 1st.

info.Brief Description:
Crude, sculptured, plaque of basalt containing Marathi 
inscription.
info.Detailed Description:
Crude, sculptured, plaque of basalt containing Marathi 
inscription on three sides horizontal lines on upper and lower 
portion and vertical lines on the right side. Sun is depicted 
on top right. In the center a woman is depicted as tending a 
donkey; she holds a knot (rope?) in her left hand.The 
inscription
is partly obliterated in the upper portion. Left and lower 
portions are broken.

info.Brief Description: Persian Inscription on a basalt slab
info.Detailed Description:
Persian Inscription on a basalt slab dated Hijri year 1001, 
Ramzan 12 (1593 A.D., June 2)Dynasty: Mughal
Ruler: Akbar Damaged on the upper portion and lower left 
portion.Refers to the order of Zahiruddin and mentions some 
officials Sarlashkar Mubarizuddin Farhad Khan, Sarnaubat 
Itimadud Daula Azam Khan and Itibar Khan in connection with 
the royal trench (alang-i-khas).

info.Brief Description: Architectural piece with Chaitya arch design
info.Detailed Description:
An architectural fragment. Probably part of the lintel of a 
religious structure (Hindu or Buddhist) with intricately carved 
chaitya arch motifs. Floral motifs are carved on the panels 
below the arch. The central arch has a heavy projecting relief 
with stellar decoration.

info.Brief Description: Architectural piece showing Dravidian style of temple sikhara
info.Detailed Description:
Architectural member resembling a tiered south Indian temple 
shikara; it has pilasters with a niche in the center which 
originally carried an image of deity.

info.Detailed Description: Oranamented Nandi sculpture. Head portion is missing.

info.Find Place: Goa Velha, Salcete taluk, South Goa
info.Brief Description: Replica of a nagara shikhara
info.Detailed Description:
Replica of a nagara shikhara. It has finials with kalasha motif 
on a stone slab.

info.Brief Description:
Viragal stone depicting in first row: one man standing holding 
the head of other man sitting. In the middle row one man 
standing holding sword and shield, other man standing in 
thribhanga. In third row worship of Agni by a man standing. 
Inscription in three lines. (Marati)
info.Detailed Description:
Inscribed Viragal in three panels. The lowermost panel 
illustrates a sati (faithful wife) about to immolate herself 
in the funeral fire of her husband who died a heroic death. 
The middle panel depicts the hero about to start a combat with 
his enemy. The uppermost panel represents the hero seated on a 
throne in heaven; he is depicted as welcoming his wife who is 
standing on his proper right side to his heavenly abode.

info.Brief Description: Mutilated, ornamented Vetala image.
info.Detailed Description:
Mutilated, ornamented Vetala image. Lower portion is broken and 
missing Vetala wears a garland of skulls and a kirita mukutha 
with depiction of snake; ribs are visible on its chest; it has 
projecting eyes and elongated ears and wears a scorpion on its 
abdomen.

info.Brief Description:
Virgal stone slab showing Shiva puja in upper row. In the middle 
row dancing and in the lower portion a Naval fight is shown.
info.Detailed Description:
Viragal in three panels depicating a naval battle. The 
lowermost panel portrays the death of the hero in a naval 
battle; it depicts a fight between warriors in two boats. The 
third boat in front is empty, its occupants presumably lying 
slain at the bottom of the sea. The middle panel shows 
apsaras lifting the hero to heaven. The uppermost panel 
illustrates the hero as seated in heaven and worshipping a 
shivalinga.

info.Brief Description: Finley carved composite Gajalakshmi sculpture in high relief.
info.Detailed Description:
Finely carved composite Gajalakshmi sculpture in high relief 
watered by two elephants on either side. The four handed deity 
is seated in padmasana (folded legs) holding lotus in both 
upper hands; attributes in lower hands are missing. Chest, 
face and head portion are mutilated. Gajalakshmi wears kiritha 
mukuta. The composite sculpture probably had adorned the 
lintel of a Hindu temple during the kadamba period.

Persian Inscription inscribed on a rectangular slab of 
Basalt. It records the royal order prohibiting the evil 
practice of Niputrik, prevalent in Mhamala gove (Goa) by 
which the property of a person having only daughters and no 
son was confiscated. The order was issued following the 
representation by malik-e-shaik, malik-zahid-Baig, and was 
conveyed to Desais and other. Date: A.H.918 (u) 1570 AD

info.Brief Description:
Four handed heavy armed sculpture of Mahisasura - Mardhini in 
half relief.
info.Detailed Description:
Four handed heavy armed sculpture of Mahisasura - Mardhini in 
half relief. The godess is represented in her furious form 
the 
Mahisasuramardini, killing the demon Mahisha; her right foot 
is resting on the ground and left foot on the back of the 
Mahisha. She is holding ayuda in three hands and a lotus in 
the upper left hand; the upper right hand is striking a sword 
into  the head of Mahisha and the lower left hand is piercing 
a dagger into the mouth of Mahisha. The goddess wears kiritha 
mukuta and prabhavali around her head.

info.Provenance: Old Talab near Bhagavati shrine of villages virnora, pernem tq. Goa.
info.Find Place: Old Talab near Bhagavati shrine of villages virnora, pernem tq. Goa.
info.Brief Description:
One image of Goddess Mahisasur-Mardini wearing Makuta Holding 
clockwise conch shell, dagger, sword and spearhead. Her left leg 
is placed on the back of demon Buffalo. The pedestal and 
prabhavali is decorated with flower motifs.
info.Detailed Description:
Four handed heavy ornamented Mahisasura-Mardhini image in 
high relief carved out of a plaque of basalt bordered by 
torana decoration. The deity wears necklace, waist band, 
armlets and kirithmukuta with a kirtimuka on top. The goddess 
is depicted  in her usual form of killing the Mahisha. Her 
upper right hand controls Mahisha with a javelin, lower right 
hand strikes a sword into Mahisha's head, and lower left hand 
pierces a dagger into Mahisha's mouth; the upper left hand 
holds a lotus. The goddess is depicted in her usual posture; 
her right leg rests on the ground and left on the back of 
Mahisha.

info.Brief Description:
Image of Vishnu prabhavali carved with Dasavathara.  Prabhavali 
broken but horse piece available. Front hands broken.
info.Detailed Description:
Richly emblished slenderly carved image of Vishnu with details 
of Dashavtara. The four handed deity wears heavy ornamentation 
- kirita mukutha (crown) necklaces, armlets, ear-rings, 
katibandha (waist band), ornamental yajnopavita (scared 
thread) and anklets; the lower portion of the image is covered 
with the characteristic costume of  vaishnative images with 
elaborate liner drapery falling from waist-line till the feet 
on either side. Three hands below the elbow are broken and 
attributes are lost. Vishnu is flank-
ed by two adoring female figures and the prabhavali around his 
head represents his Dashavtara Matsya, kurma, Varaha, Vamana, 
Narasinvha, Rama, Parshurama, Krishna, Buddha, Kalki etc.

info.Brief Description: A sculpture in stone of Surya.
info.Detailed Description:
Richly embllished standing image of Suryadeva (sungod) flanked 
by attendants- danda and pingala. The two handed deity holds 
full blown lotuses in both the hands; the image is depicted 
with heavy ornamentation - kiritha mukutha, karnakundala, 
necklaces, chest ornamentation, katibanda (waist band). The 
deity wears boot till the knees- probably the influence of 
kushana art.The personification of Surya and his worship as a 
deity with other deities like Shiva, Vishnu, Shakti and Ganesha 
became popular in India from the Gupta period. Surya had been 
worshipped as a deity from ancient times by the Hindu 
populations of Goa region.

info.Brief Description: Complete viragal (hero stone) representing the immolation of a hero.
info.Detailed Description:
Complete viragal (hero stone) representing the immolation of a 
hero by his decapitation. The lowermost panel plastically 
represents the decapitation; the hero is seated cross legged 
on a throne; his hands are folded in gesture of prayer; 
although his head has already been cut off and is shown in 
front of his throne, a person on his proper right side is seen 
with a raised sword in his hand as if about to cut the head 
off.Another person in the right corner is depicted playing a 
drum. The middle panel depicts the dead
hero on his way to heaven flanked by musicians who are playing 
drum and gong.The third panel illustrates the hero worshipping 
a shivalinga in heaven,flanked by two persons who are 
assisting him.

info.Brief Description: Damaged viragal with representation of self immolation.
info.Detailed Description:
Damaged viragal with representation of self immolation. The 
hero is seated cross legged and folded hands; his head  has 
already been cut off, and shown in front of his folded legs, 
but a person on his proper right side is standing with a 
raised sword in hand as if about to cut the head off. The 
middle panel depicts a seated person in a gesture of ordering 
to a smaller person (who is standing with sword and shield) 
whose identification is open to discussion. The top panel 
depicts a galloping horse which is 
damaged. The viragal can be assigned to 12th century AD, 
because of its bold relief.

info.Brief Description: Bi-panelled hero-cum-sati stone.
info.Detailed Description:
Bi-panelled hero-cum-sati stone commemorating a hero who died 
a heroic death and his faithful wife who followed him to the 
pyre (funeral fire). The lowermost panel represents the 
faithful wife standing with folded hands before her husband's 
pyre. Ready to self immolate; she is flanked be devotees. 
Musicians are depicted within a structural frame just below 
the sati; they are playing drum and gong. The upper panel 
illustrates the enthroned hero in heaven seated on a high 
throne and his wife on a lower throne to his left side. The 
heroic couple are shown as attended and worshipped by apsaras 
and devotees. The roof topping of the slab has a kalasha on 
its apex which is slightly damaged.

info.Brief Description: Viragal (hero stone) in low relief.
info.Detailed Description:
Viragal (hero stone) in low relief with depiction of self 
immolation of hero by his decapitation. The lowermost panel 
plastically depicts the ritual of self immolation; the hero is 
seated cross legged on a throne with folded hands;although his 
head has already been cut off, and is shown in front of his 
throne, one person on his proper left side is seen with a 
raised sword as if about to cut the head off. Two persons to 
the hero's right side are playing drum and gong. The middle 
panel illustrates the hero being lifted to heaven by the 
apsaras. In the uppermost panel the hero is seen in heaven 
worshipping a shivalinga.

info.Brief Description: Broken head of a huge bearded vetal image

info.Brief Description:
Viragal representing self immolation of the hero by his 
decapitation.
info.Detailed Description:
Viragal representing self immolation of the hero by his 
decapitation. The lowermost panel illustrates the ritual of 
head offering by the hero. The middle panel depicts a battle 
scene; a person on elephant back, protected under a parasol, 
is engaged in a fight against foot soldiers. The uppermost 
panel shows the hero seated on a throne in heaven protected 
under a parasol.

info.Brief Description:
Viragal stone depicted in the upper row two females holding a 
warrior in asana. In middle row a battle and in the third row 
depicted two person in Padmasana.
info.Detailed Description:
Three panelled Viragal topped by a kalasha (vase) motif. The 
lower panel plastically represents the immolation of two 
persons by their decapitation. The heroes are seated on two 
thrones with folded hands, although their heads are cut off 
and shown in front of their thrones two persons are shown as 
raising weapons as if to cut off the heads. The middle panel 
depicts one decapitated hero being lifted by celestial beings 
and the uppermost panel illustrate the other hero being 
carried to heaven by two apsaras (celestial damsels).

info.Brief Description:
Virgal stone depicting in upper row the shivpuja, in the middle 
portion a dance and in  the lower portion a person is shown 
(broken in three pieces)
info.Detailed Description:
Broken Viragal in three panels punctuated by decorative 
crossbars. All three panels are broken.The lowermost panel 
which usually illustrates the cause of hero's death is 
broken. 
The middle panel represents the hero being carried to heaven 
by a mob of apsaras. The uppermost panel depicts the hero 
seated in heaven, worsipping a shivalinga; a person, probably 
a dwarpalaka holding a sword and a shield is guarding 
him.This memorial stone can be assigned to 13th cent. A.D. 
(later phase of  Goa Kadambas) because the heads of the 
figures increase disproportionately to the size of their 
bodies

info.Brief Description:
One relief of Ravalnath in half relief. It is broken in four 
pieces. The head is mutilated. A  little evidence is left. 
Legs 
below the knee broken . It is in the very bad state of 
preservation.The image of Ravalnath was worshipped as a 
'Bhkshatanamurthi' or 'Pari- varadevata' (family god) by the 
Hindu populations of Goa, particularly the cattle raising 
communities during ancient and medieval times.
info.Detailed Description:
Crude relief sculpture of four handed Ravalnath. Head and Legs 
below the knee are broken. Attributes are lost. The image of 
Ravalnath was conceived as a form of Shiva by the Hindu 
populations of Goa through the ages.

info.Brief Description: Model of fort of Diu
info.Detailed Description:
Model of fort of Diu showing two different styles of 
fortification: (i) the usual style consisting of round 
bastions prevailant all over the world which was known in 
Europe as the old Italian style (bastions broken at places). 
(ii) Later, as a second belt of fortification, wall I was 
added in 'heco' i.e.Italian
in style consisting of heart shaped bastions which contained 
mathematical gunfire storerooms with hidden openings in front 
of the rampart walls. This special fortification design was 
invented in Italy towards the middle of 16th century from 
where it had spread to all over Europe. With the advent of 
Portuguese, this style travelled to India. Cast-Plaster Caster 
Cement.

info.Detailed Description: Religious painting of a saint probably St.Francis of Assisi.

info.Brief Description: Stone panel sculpture. Hero stone in two panels. Fragmentary.
info.Detailed Description:
Much damaged viragal with two extant panels; the lower panel 
which usually depicts  the cause of the hero's death is 
damaged beyond identification. The upper (extant) panel 
depicts the dead hero being lifted to heaven five apsaras; 
the 
uppermost panel representing the hero's usual seat in heaven 
is broken and missing.

info.Brief Description:
Stone.Sculpture.Architectural piece.Corbel stone of church 
pillar.Scroll design.
info.Detailed Description:
Scroll Capital of an Ionic column ornamented with egg and dart 
decorative band; the shaft is faulted.

info.Brief Description:
Architectural member. Stone sculpture. Architectural piece, 
Corbel stone of church pillar.
info.Detailed Description:
Much damaged capital of a composite column with traces of 
acanthus and scrolls.

info.Brief Description:
Sculpture double sided.  One side Hindu Temple frieze 
fragmentary.  The other side basement or lower part of a church 
pillar.
info.Detailed Description:
Basement of a pillar with base mouldings and the panel at one side and 
backside broken images of Hindu gods. probably reused the stone of Pre 
Portuguese in construction of church.

info.Brief Description:
Sculpture from church a devil. Skeleton, middle position above 
knee missing.
info.Detailed Description:
Skeleton image on the pilaster of a Christian structure 
representing death.

(octagonal) in the middle, and Shivbhaga (round) on top.
info.Detailed Description:

info.Brief Description: Indo Portuguese stamp
info.Detailed Description:
Indo Portuguese stamp
One rupee stamp with symbol of Holy cross and bells; number 
denomination on top right corner with legend "ANO SANTO MCML 
INDIA PORTUGUESA" at the bottom. Number denomination 1 in bold. 
A man with bells and cross.

Portuguese overseas stamp forty escudos with bust of Filipe Nery Xavier in the center; value of the stamp $ 40 on the lower left and legend Republica Portuguesa on top and Estado da India at the bottom.

info.Brief Description: Portuguese overseas stamp for estado da India; Rs. 6.
info.Detailed Description:
Portuguese overseas stamp for estado da India; 6 Rs.
6 rupee stamp with figure of navigator Vasco da Gama in the center, Portuguese colonial emblem on upper corners, the legend Imperio colonial Portuguese on top; value of the stamp 6 Rs. On lower corners with legend "CORREIOS EASTADO DA INDIA" at the bottom.

info.Brief Description:
Oil painting on wood, portrait of George Cabral,Governor from 
1549 to 1551 A.D./ Restored by 
goanese De Costa in 1894 A.D.
info.Detailed Description:
Period- as Governor 1549-1551
 becoming governor he was in command of 
Bassein. He served the office 
of Governor for sixteen 
months.   He resisted the attack of 
the trucks. he with the help of king of Covhin suppressed the 
opposition of the Zomorin and the King of Pimiento. Jorge Cabral 
was brought up in India and knew the Indian set-up very well. He 
was keen in looking after the king's treasure.
 In 1550, he gave grants to the college of Santa Fe or St. 
Paul and later on, he enlarged 
it for the increasing number 
of students .He was accounted one of the 
best governors of the Portuguese eastern dominions.
